title: When will the Delta variant (B.1.617.2) first represent more than 67.0% of COVID cases in the US?
possible_answers: The two weeks ending 3 July 2021 or earlier
The two weeks ending either 17 July 2021 or 31 July 2021
The two weeks ending either 14 August 2021 or 28 August 2021
The two weeks ending 11 September 2021 or 25 September 2021
correct_answer: The two weeks ending either 17 July 2021 or 31 July 2021
preds: Mistake, confused Jul and Aug, ignore this, see next forecast.
I don't really get this question, and the CDC data tracker is fairly confusing/feels very clumsy to me.

I'm going to review this again, as I still think there is an option for the two weeks ending 3 July. It is only a very slim chance, but I shouldn't rule it out without checking. Not only has the June 19th figure been updated from 26% to 30.4%, there is also almost no sequencing data to work with from June 26th onwards; barely 150 sequenced case results for the entire United States in the remaining week, compared to over 2,680 for the comparable period two weeks prior to that. 
In other words the latest report seems approx 1 week out of date, and has a wide margin of error based on a projection, and the few states that have reported since 26th June. Otherwise it will certainly be within the two weeks after this, of that I am more certain :-)
UPDATED: I think the date 67% prevalence is reached will be approx 01-05 July (following rate of change of prevalence and sequencing data), but due to aggregating a two-week period, this will most likely be recorded as two-weeks ending 17 July. This may not show up for a further few weeks as sequencing data comes in, and the nowcast total is updated.
Definitely looks like I underestimated this, looking likely to happen in July.

51.7% as of July 3 w/ 95% CI 46.3-57%  The nowcast of 26.1 was actually updated to 30.4% so I would be incredibly surprised to not see 67% in the next 4 weeks.  Bumping to 100% now that the July 3 hurdle has been cleared.

The new nowcast is out! Delta came in at 30.4% for the period ending 6/19, and the nowcast puts Delta at 51.7% for the 2 weeks ending July 3, with a 95% CI of 46.3% to 57.0%. I think it's clear that 67.0% will be reached imminently, so I'm zeroing out bin 3. How far up will the nowcast for July 3 be revised? The June 19 nowcast was revised upwards to 26% and now to 30.4%. I don't think it's likely that the nowcast from July 3 will be revised from 51.7% all the way to >67.0%. That would also require the percentage for July 3 to be more than double that for the period ending June 19. This forecast is done. Also, as the curve of Delta prevalence is a logistic curve, consider the situation from another angle:
2 weeks ending June 19 to 2 weeks ending July 3: from 30.4% to 51.7%, i.e., almost 50%.
Because the logistic curve for Delta prevalence is roughly symmetric around 50%, we should expect to see a little more than 51.7% + (51.7% - 30.4%) = 73% for the 2 weeks ending July 17. So I'll predict the July 17 number will come in at ~75%, barring changes in the nowcast for July 3.

The nowcast for 7/3 now is available and shows a 51.7% prevalence for delta (pretty much in line with expectations). Based on the proportion of new delta cases, I expect 67% threshold will be surpassed in 2 - 3 weeks : https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#variant-proportions

I cannot find any updated report on CDC tracker webpage beyond June 5th. 
Various estimates of between 25% to 50% could be found as of July 5th. https://www.masslive.com/coronavirus/2021/07/delta-variant-accounts-for-over-25-of-us-coronavirus-cases-according-to-cdc-data.html & https://twitter.com/EricTopol/status/1412065037162663936 (thanks to @JonathanMann )
In all likelihood, it will be more than 2/3 of the cases by the end of July 2021.

The delta variant is growing quickly, jumping from 2.9% to 10.0% in the two-week period ending 5 June. Fauci said on 23 June that the proportion had grown to 20%. This rate of growth shows no sign of slowing, and I think it is safe to assume the proportion of delta cases will increase by another 20-25% per two weeks into the near future. This estimate gives 17 or 31 July as the most likely dates for delta to reach 67.0%.  The common vaccines in the US are potentially less protective against delta variant transmission, so as inoculation rates rise, the delta variant will have more of an advantage over other strains. However, US vaccine distribution has slowed and seems to be reaching a plateau.

Delta is progressing so quickly, it seems like something unusual would have to happen in order for it to not fall into the second bucket (or possibly the first bucket when considering measurement error) : https://twitter.com/EricTopol/status/1412065037162663936
CDC Nowcast prediction for 06/19 shows 26.1% - which has been updated from 20.6%. B1 has a  slim chance, but B2 seems overwhelmingly likely now.

Similar forecast to previous 10th-20th July, but it could perhaps be even earlier.

26.1% as of 6/19.   In 2 wk intervals we have: 0.6% 1.3% 2.9% 10% 26.1% Using exponential regression we get 0.202 * 2.608^(wk) using the 2 weeks ending 6/19 as wk #5. With this we would expect 63.56% for the two weeks ending July 3.  Thus, it is almost a certainty that the US hits 67% at least in the two weeks ending 7/17 or 7/31.

The Delta variant now makes up over 20% of US Covid Cases as of a few days ago: https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/how-dangerous-is-the-delta-variant-and-will-it-cause-a-covid-surge-in-the-u-s/. It makes up about 25% of cases today: https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/cdc-covid-cases-10-percent-hypertransmissible-delta-variant-spreads-n1272895. It is stated in the question that the Delta Variant had a share of 2.7% in the US in the week ending May 22 2021. Since vaccination rates are slowing, let's assume for the sake of simplicity that that effect has already fully taken place in the population from late May to early July. We know infections spread roughly exponentially (admittedly this is a large assumption, but just for a simplistic model), so let's say that we can model the spread as c*r^t where r is some fixed rate, t is number of weeks since the week ending in May 22 2021, and c is some initial constant, namely 2.7%. In 5.5 weeks til the end of June we have 2.7*r^(5.5)=20 -> r ~ 1.44. If we just set this number of weeks at 5 or 6 we get r = 1.5 and 1.4 respectively. For r=1.4 we have 2.7*1.4^t > 67 so we need t > 9.5, for r=1.44 we have t > 8.8, and for r=1.5 we need 7.9. In the 6 weeks from May 22 to Jul 1, we need 2.7*r^6 ~ 25, and we can see r=1.44 works about the best. The accuracy of this fit means that this model selected cannot be immediately rejected from our current data points. All these choices lie within the second possibility. So the second option definitely seems like the most likely possibility with this in mind. It is possible that there is some noise with this estimate, admittedly. With this analysis in mind the last two possibilities seem far too unlikely, especially considering that America does not contain COVID particularly well as James noted, so I give these possibilities a 5% and a 1% probability respectively. It's already July 2 and the percentage is about 20% so the chance of the first choice is clearly 0%. This gives the third possibility a 19% chance which seems reasonable.
Going higher in second bucket based on increase in Nowcast

I'm assuming delta will follow about the same path as B.1.1.7. For the two weeks ending March 13th, B.1.1.7 was at 26.9%. Delta is at 10% now, the NowCast estimates  20.6% on the 19th. From March 13th, it took until the week ending 4/14 to get to 66%. But it also topped out at 70%, so it's possible delta never gets to 67%, especially if it never fully supplants B.1.1.7. Or a new variant could emerge that takes share away from delta or slows its growth. So I'm guessing about a month and a half from the 19th for when it may hit, with an almost equally likely scenario being that delta does not hit 67%.

Currently delta transmissions are estimated to be growing at 2.08x every two weeks; however, the growth rate in the prior fortnight was 3.67x. So the growth  seems to have slowed down by 1.59x. I have used median of two past growth rates and median of that with the reduction in growth rate to arrive at 2.23x. These calculations suggest 8th July as the probable date for 67% transmissions. Given that the growth rate is slowing down, let's hope delta gives up under the influence of vaccines! b2: Thickest part of the distribution.
b3: meant as a proxy for factors that selectively slow down the delta variant.
